intro: Rivina portulaccoides, commonly known as the Mexican firecracker, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring succulent, fleshy leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces vibrant orange-red flowers in clusters, which bloom during the summer months. Its leaves are adapted to store water, making it drought-tolerant and suitable for xeriscaping. It is also known for its ability to thrive in poor soils and full sun conditions.
